lines: You are exploring the playpen and are feeling very lively. Like a prizefighter you grab hold of the playpen bars and shake back and forth, flexing your knees.
You raise your hands over your head triumphantly...BOOM! You go right down on your bottom. (Thank heaven for padded bottoms.) You wobble back up to standing position.
#NAVIGATE AROUND THE CRIB HOLDING ON TO THE BARS
With ballet-like movements you step over the musical ball and four stuffed animals. You've perfected this form of locomotion. Would you like to let go again?
BOOM! Ouch! You crash to the floor like a sack of potatoes (your rear end is beginning to feel sore). Want to try one more time?

The thrill of victory! You stumble across the crib like a punch-drunk sailor and firmly grasp the rail on the other side. You've taken your first steps! Soon you will be tripping the light fantastic, chasing women and running away
The agony of defeat. You teeter on one leg for what seems like an eternity, do a half spin and bounce off the floor. That's enough for now. You'll get the hang of it sooner or later.
You give up much too easily! It's going to look pretty funny when you are the only IBM executive who crawls into work on all fours.
You rock back and forth and crash to the floor. Want to try again?
You are facing the wrong way. You walk into the playpen and fall right on your back. Your head hits the mat with a loud THUNK! This can get dangerous. Want to try again?
Your determination allows you to concentrate on the task at hand.
#LOOK STRAIGHT AHEAD AND TAKE A STEP
You can't see where you are going! Your head is down and throwing your balance off. You spin around 180 degrees and...grab the railing just before you fall to the mat. Want to try again?

You look ahead and thrust your arms out in front of you like Frankenstein's monster. You shift your weight from side to side, but become front-heavy. You fall on your arms and hands, and bump your chin on the mat. Want to try again?
You are showing early signs of confidence, mixed with just the right amount of risk taking.
Success comes easily and naturally as you take a leisurely (but wobbly) stroll to the other side of the crib. Which way to the Olympics?

Even the most confident of sorts meets with an occasional flop, which is literally what you do. You pick yourself up for a second try and have limited success. Two small steps for baby, one giant leap for babykind.
